channel.title: Aravind Reddy on Aravind Reddy
channel.description: Recent content in Aravind Reddy on Aravind Reddy

item.title: Space Bounded Complexity classes and Derandomization
item.description: In this talk, we will give an introduction to Space Bounded Complexity classes and give an overview of $BPL \subseteq \text{SPACE}(\log^2 n)$ result by Nisan. For space bounded complexity classes, we will follow the lecture notes by Prof. Luca Trevisan and for the $BPL \subseteq \text{SPACE}(\log^2 n)$ result, we will follow the lecture notes by Prof. Jonathan Katz.

item.title: High Dimensional Expanders
item.description: In this talk, we will give an introduction to High Dimensional Expanders, an area which has seen immense interest recently from the TCS community. Specifically, we will discuss Simplicial Complexes, Local Spectral Expanders, and Random walks on Simplicial Complexes.

item.title: Cup Games
item.description: In this talk, we will provide an introduction to cup games and discuss some recent results and techniques from a STOC 2019 paper by Bender et.al.

item.title: Markov Chains and Random Walks on Networks
item.description: The talk included 2 parts: A general introduction to Finite Markov Chains, and an introduction to Random walks on Networks(with their connection to electrical networks). The content for the talk was mostly from Chapters 1, 2, and 8 of the book Markov Chains and Mixing Times by David Levin and Yuval Peres.

item.title: Contrastive Unsupervised Representation Learning
item.description: The content for the talk was mostly taken from one of Arora et.al’s blog posts on offconvex.org and their paper A Theoretical Analysis of Contrastive Unsupervised Representation Learning. The first time I came across this paper was through a plenary talk given by Sanjeev Arora at ALT 2019.

item.title: Bilu-Linial Stable instances of Graph Partioniong problems
item.description: The content for the talk was mostly taken from the SODA’14 paper titled Bilu-Linial Stable Instances of Max Cut and Minimum Multiway Cut by Makarychev, Makarychev, and Vijayaraghavan. The presentation style and some of the examples were inspired by Tim Roughgarden’s lecture on the same topic.

item.title: Why are there so few women in science?
item.description: I just read an NYTimes article titled “Why are there Still So Few Women in Science?”. I thought that I had an idea about gender bias in academia but I was very wrong. This article definitely made an impact on me and I highly recommend reading the entire article.

item.title: Generalization theory for Deep Learning
item.description: The content for the talk was mostly taken from one of Sanjeev Arora’s blog posts on offconvex.org and Understanding deep learning requires re-thinking generalization, which won a Best Paper award at ICLR 2017.

item.title: Ascending the Categorial Heights!
item.description: After hearing a lot about Category Theory from Tushant, I wanted to know more about it and started reading Category Theory - A Gentle Introduction by Peter Smith. It feels great till where I’ve read.

item.title: Indian Classical Music
item.description: I’ve recently started appreciating Indian Classical music. Many thanks to Tushant for introducing me to this wonderful art form. I recently had the oppurtunity to attend a sarod recital by Pandit Abhishek Lahiri accompanied by Soumen Nandy on the tabla. The event was organised by SPIC MACAY, IITK.

item.title: Computer Networks
item.description: I’m reading a book on Computer Networks right now for a course and I feel awesome getting to know about tonnes of stuff which I’ve been using throughout my life ðŸ˜„

item.title: Emmy Noether
item.description: While I was reading about the Translation operator today, I stumbled upon the wiki for Emmy Noether - famous for “Noether’s theorem” which tells us that conservation laws follow from the symmetry properties of nature. It was interesting to note that she had worked at a German institute for seven years without pay because at that time(~1910), women were largely excluded from academic positions. This was comforting to me because I was feeling sad about the fact that I only started learning CS after I started my undergrad. It made me feel that I should accept the fact that nobody is on an equal footing when it comes to anything in life and this is what precisely defines our distinct perspective of life.

item.title: Randomness for Decisions
item.description: I was in a dilemma today whether I should study for the Machine Learning course or whether I should study for the Coherence & Quantum Entanglement course in the next three hours. I was totally unable to choose between them and so a lot of my brain’s computational power was being sucked up by this decision task. I finally decided to go with Octave’s random number generator. Just used unidrnd(2) ðŸ˜„

item.title: Ugly Duckling theorem
item.description:
Yes, I know, my last post said that I would be shifting my blog from wordpress to a Jekyll Hugo based blog hosted with Github pages. But I’m procrastinating. Anyway, putting that aside, let’s get to the meat of the post. Check out the Ugly duckling theorem. It’s pretty dope. I encountered it in the introductory lecture slides for the course on Machine Learning I’m doing right now(yikes! ML ooh).

Yeah, don’t judge me. I’m not doing ML because EVERYONE is doing ML but because I need to complete a couple of courses from a subset of CS courses to get my CS degree from IITK and it so happens that among those courses, ML is the most theoretical(the other courses are mostly from systems and I (sort of) despise systems courses).
